literal_meaning: To throw dust at the sun.
figurative_meaning: Trying to harm someone will only harm yourself.
example: You are throwing dust at the sun; this will only backfire on you.

idiom: હિંમત એ મર્દા તો મદદ એ ખૂદા
literal_meaning: God helps those who help themselves.
figurative_meaning: Efforts will lead to divine assistance.
example: This saying is true; those who work hard will achieve success.

idiom: જ્યાં સુધી શ્વાસ ત્યાં સુધી આશ
literal_meaning: As long as there is breath, there is hope.
figurative_meaning: Never give up; keep trying until the end.
example: As long as there is breath, there is hope; we should never lose faith.

literal_meaning: If the mind is good, even ordinary water seems like Ganga.
figurative_meaning: A positive mindset makes everything seem better.
example: This saying holds true; positive thoughts make life beautiful.

literal_meaning: While fixing one thing, another breaks.
figurative_meaning: Problems tend to multiply when trying to solve them.
example: It often happens that while solving one problem, another arises.

idiom: લક્ષ્મી ચાલો કરવા આવે તો મોં ધોવા ન જવું
literal_meaning: When opportunity knocks, do not waste time.
figurative_meaning: Act quickly when a chance arises.
example: It’s true that when opportunity comes, don’t waste time washing your face.

figurative_meaning: Both parties are responsible in a conflict.
example: This means that in any dispute, both sides have roles to play.

literal_meaning: What is spoken will be sold.
figurative_meaning: Speaking up is essential for being heard.
example: It’s important to express your opinion; what is spoken will be sold.

idiom: કિડી ને કાન ને હાથી ને મન
literal_meaning: To each according to his needs.
example: This means that everyone receives according to their needs.

literal_meaning: Too much greed is the root of sin.
example: Excessive greed is the root of sin; as people become greedier, they stray from the right path.

literal_meaning: Not all that glitters is gold.
example: Not everything that glitters is gold means don't trust appearances because not everything is true.

literal_meaning: To kill two birds with one stone.
figurative_meaning: Achieving multiple goals with a single effort.
example: I was able to accomplish two tasks at once; it was like killing two birds with one stone.

literal_meaning: In a deserted village, even a fool acts as a leader.
figurative_meaning: People often overestimate their knowledge in unfamiliar situations.
example: In deserted places, even fools think they are wise.

literal_meaning: The lazy one will not achieve anything.
example: The lazy person will not achieve anything without hard work.

literal_meaning: Two heads are better than one.
example: Let's work together; two heads are better than one.

idiom: મોર ના ઇંડા ચિતરવા ના પડે
literal_meaning: Peacock eggs do not need painting.
figurative_meaning: Talented people shine regardless of circumstances.
example: Talented individuals stand out on their own without needing extra embellishment.

literal_meaning: Don't count your chickens before they hatch.
figurative_meaning: Don't assume success before it happens.
example: It's wise to wait for results rather than assume outcomes too early.
